title: GM’s strike will cost the company about $50 million a day
text:
General Motors Co. stock losses intensified Monday, the first business day of a strike that has seen nearly 50,000 workers walk out across the U.S.

GM shares GM, -4.25% were headed for their lowest close in three weeks and on pace for their largest one-day percentage decrease since mid-August. The shares have fallen for four straight sessions, losing nearly 5% in that period.

Analysts at RBC Capital Markets estimated that each day of the strike, the first major walkout at GM since 2007, would cost the company about $40 million to $50 million in profit before interest and taxes.

“Major sticking points” for the United Automobile Workers include limiting the number of temporary workers the company is allowed to use, “giving new members a faster route to senior-level wager of >$30/hour,” the RBC Capital analysts said.

Negotiations were scheduled to take place Monday.

See also: Why the striking workers at General Motors are so extraordinary

GM’s U.S. inventory is relatively high, or running about 77 days versus the industry’s about 61 days, the RBC analysts said.

GM may have “prebuilt” some vehicles as a buffer against a strike risk, so consumers shouldn’t really feel much of an impact, but “clearly the longer a strike persists, the greater magnitude of a headwind for the company,” the analysts said.

If history is any guide, “any temporary strike-related stock weakness will be quickly bought,” analysts at Evercore ISI said in their note.

The current strike affects more than 31 GM plants, or the majority of the company’s North American production. In 2007, about 70,000 workers were on strike for two days, they said.

GM has offered workers more than $7 billion in U.S. investments, higher pay, and other enticements. In a statement, the company said it was “disappointing” that UAW’s leadership “has chosen to strike.”

See also: 4 things investors need to know as GM workers go on strike

The UAW said it did not make the decision to strike “lightly.”

“We are committed to a strong contract at GM that recognizes our UAW members, who make some of the greatest products in the world and make GM so profitable,” the union said in its statement.

GM shares have gained 12% so far this year, underperforming the 20% and 16% gains for the S&P 500 index SPX, -0.31% and the Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIA, -0.52% .
